questions.question: Which of the following sheet is larger in size?

explanations.a: A0 is the largest sheet in the ISO A series with dimensions 841 × 1189 mm and an area of 1 square meter. Each subsequent size (A1, A2, etc.) is exactly half the area of the previous size.

questions.question: Harder grade pencils are denoted with B, 2B, 3B, 4B, etc.

explanations.b: This statement is false. B grades (B, 2B, 3B, 4B, etc.) represent softer pencils. Harder pencils are denoted by the H series (H, 2H, 3H, 4H, etc.), where higher numbers indicate harder leads.

questions.question: What is the primary unit of measurement for engineering drawings?

explanations.c: Millimetres are the standard unit of measurement in engineering drawings because they provide the necessary precision for technical specifications while being practical for dimensioning components and assemblies.

questions.question: What is the angle set between the scales of the drafter?

explanations.c: The scales in a mini drafter are fixed at 90° to each other. This perpendicular arrangement allows for easy drawing of horizontal and vertical lines, as well as accurate measurement in both directions.

questions.question: A set square is used in combination with a T-square to draw horizontal lines.

explanations.a: This is true. The set square rests against the T-square's blade, using it as a guide. While the T-square itself draws horizontal lines, the set square can be positioned to draw vertical lines and various angles when used in combination.

questions.question: Which of the following angle is not possible to be made using a single set square?

explanations.c: 75° cannot be constructed using a single standard set square. Standard set squares have angles of 30°-60°-90° and 45°-45°-90°. To construct 75°, you would need to combine two set squares or use other geometric construction methods.

questions.question: The main visible outlines of a drawing are represented by _______.

explanations.b: Main visible outlines are represented by continuous wide lines (thick lines) according to IS standards. These lines clearly distinguish the main features of the object from other elements like hidden lines, center lines, or construction lines.
